choices.text: Superior meatus
Middle meatus
Inferior meatus

questions.text: The tears secreted by the lacrimal glands are drained via the lacrimal drainage apparatus into which part of the nose?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior meatus

 

Options C:

 

  • The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and post 2/3rd. It is guarded by a mucosal fold known as Valve of Hasner or Plica lacrimalis.
  • DO NOT CONFUSE: Valve of Rosenmuller is situated at the junction of common canaliculus and lacrimal sac.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Middle meatus:

 

It is site of opening of the nasolacrimal duct after Dacryocystorhinostomy. (DCR)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The opening of the nasolacrimal duct is located in the inferior meatus.

 

Ref: pg 459/ / Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Anita, a 32-year-old female patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a complaint of persistent tearing since several months and occasional eye discharge in her left eye. She notices that her left eye frequently waters, especially when she is outdoors or exposed to windy conditions. She has no history of eye trauma or previous eye surgeries. The ophthalmologist suspects a nasolacrimal duct obstruction in the left eye. What is the normal length of the duct involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 12 to 18 mm

 

Option C:

 

  • Nasolacrimal duct drains the tears by extending downwards from the lacrimal sac and opening into the inferior meatus of the nose which is guarded by Valve of Hasner to prevent reflux.

  • Length= 18mm (12 to 24mm)

  • Diameter = 3mm

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 5 to 10 mm: This length is of the body of the lacrimal sac.

 

Option B. 20 to 25 mm: This is the length of the inferior meatus.

 

Option D. 1 to 2 mm: This is the length of the vertical part of the canaliculus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal length of the nasolacrimal duct, which drains tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity, is approximately 12 to 18 mm

 

Ref: pg 459/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Downwards, backwards and medially
Upwards, inwards and backwards
Downwards, outwards and forwards
Downwards, backwards and laterally

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with persistent tearing, recurrent eye infections, and crusting around the left eye since birth. The pediatrician suspects nasolacrimal duct obstruction and suggests Crigler’s massage and prescribes antibiotics. In which direction is the involved duct directed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Downwards, backwards and laterally

 

Explanation:

 

The NLD runs in a bony canal formed by maxilla and inferior turbinate directed downwards, backwards and laterally.

 

Students should read the question carefully. The direction of the NLD is not to be confused with the direction of the canaliculus which is directed medially.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 The nasolacrimal duct is directed downwards, backwards and laterally.

 

Ref: pg 459/ / Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: At the junction of lacrimal sac and NLD
In the middle part of NLD
At the opening of NLD in the inferior meatus
Between the common canaliculus and lacrimal sac

questions.text: The most common cause of congenital lacrimal sac obstruction is due to imperforate Valve of Hasner. Where is this valve located?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) At the opening of NLD in the inferior meatus

 

Option C:

 

  • The lumen of the nasolacrimal duct is marked by numerous folds of mucous membrane, known as the valves.
  • Valve of Hasner is situated in the lower end of NLD at the inferior meatus.
  • It prevents the entry of the air into the lacrimal sac, when air is blown out of a closed nose.

 

Explanation:

 

Option D - Between Common Canaliculus and Lacrimal Sac: This is the location of the Valve of Rosenmuller.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The valve of Hasner is located at the opening of NLD in inferior meatus.

 

 

Ref: pg 460 / Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Surface ectoderm

questions.text: Lacrimal glands are derived from which embryonic layer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Surface ectoderm

 

Option A:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Mesoderm: The mesoderm forms structures such as muscles, bones, connective tissues, and parts of the cardiovascular and lymphatic systems. It is not involved in the development of the lacrimal glands.

 

Option C. Neuroectoderm: The neuroectoderm primarily gives rise to the central and peripheral nervous systems, including the brain and spinal cord. It is not responsible for the development of the lacrimal glands.

 

Option D. Neuroectoderm & mesoderm: This combination is incorrect for the development of the lacrimal glands. While both neuroectoderm and mesoderm are crucial for various aspects of embryonic development, they do not contribute to the formation of the lacrimal glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lacrimal glands are derived from the surface ectoderm

 

Ref: pg 12/ COMPREHENSIVE ophthalmology/ 6th edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Gland of Moll
Gland of Zeis
Gland of Krausse

questions.text: Identify the gland marked with a red arrow:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meibomian gland

 

Option A:

 

  • They are modified sweat glands.
  • Embedded on tarsal plates, hence also known as Tarsal glands.
  • Openings are arranged in a single row on the lid margin between grey line & posterior border.
  • Secrete outermost lipid layer of tear film.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Gland of Moll: These are apocrine sweat glands found in the eyelids. They are different from the tarsal (Meibomian) glands and are associated with the hair follicles of the eyelashes.

 

Option C. Gland of Zeis: These are small sebaceous glands associated with the eyelashes and are not the same as the tarsal glands. They secrete a substance that lubricates the eyelashes.

 

Option D. Gland of Krausse: These are minor glands in the eyelid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tarsal glands are the same as the Meibomian glands, which are sebaceous glands within the eyelids contributing to the tear film.

 

Ref: pg 497/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: The glands of Zeis open into?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lash follicle

 

Option C:

 

  • Glands of Zeis are specialised sebaceous glands which open into hair (eyelash) follicle, like other sebaceous glands.
  • Glands of Moll are specialised sweat glands located behind hair follicle. They also open into the hair follicle or the duct of Zeis glands, but not directly onto skin, unlike other sweat glands.

 

 

  • Stye/ Hordeolum externum is a suppurative inflammation of Zeis gland.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Conjunctiva: The glands of Zeis do not open into the conjunctiva. The conjunctiva is a mucous membrane.

 

Option B. Lacrimal sac: The lacrimal sac is part of the tear drainage system and is not connected to the glands of Zeis. It collects tears from the eyes and drains them into the nasolacrimal duct.

 

Option D. Lid margin: Meibomian glands open at the lid margin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The glands of Zeis open into the eyelash follicles (Option C). They are sebaceous glands that secrete an oily substance to lubricate the eyelashes.

 

Ref: pg 499/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: The lacrimal gland is present in which quadrant of the orbit?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superolateral

 

Option A:

 

MAIN LACRIMAL GLAND: 2 lobes

 

  • Orbital/ Superior lobe:
    • Almond shaped
    • Located in lacrimal fossa which is in superolateral quadrant.
    • Secretions carried by 10 to 12 lacrimal ducts traversing palpebral lobe and open on the conjunctival surface.
  • Palpebral/ Inferior lobe:
    • 1 or 2 lobules separated from orbital part by Levator Palpebrae Superioris.

 

ACCESSORY LACRIMAL GLANDS: Glands of Krause and Wolfring

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Inferolateral: The inferolateral quadrant contains other structures like the orbital floor and muscles.

 

Option C. Superonasal: This area includes structures such as the trochlea of the superior oblique muscle.

 

Option D. Inferonasal:  It includes other anatomical structures like the nasolacrimal duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lacrimal gland is located in the superolateral quadrant of the orbit

 

Ref: pg 386/ LACRIMAL APPARATUS/ Comprehensive ophthalmology/ AK KHURANA/ 6th edition

questions.text:
The order of different layers in the tear film from anterior to posterior are:

 

L-lipid, M-mucous, A- aqueous
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L-A-M

 

Option A:

 

The 3 layers of tear film include

 

LIPID -  AQUEOUS – MUCOUS

 

  • Lipid layer secreted by the meibomian glands.
  • Aqueous layer secreted by the lacrimal glands.
  • Mucous layer secreted principally by conjunctival goblet cells

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The layers of the tear film are Lipid-Aqueous-Mucus.

 

Ref: Pg 461/ Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

choices.text: Tear film break up time
None of the above

questions.text: Identify the test:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Jones test

 

Option C:

 

JONES - to check the patency of lacrimal drainage pathway with fluorescein.

 

The given image is of a positive primary Jones dye test.

 

  • The primary test: differentiates partial obstruction of the lacrimal passages and lacrimal pump failure from primary hypersecretion of tears.
  • The secondary (irrigation) test: Identifies lacrimal pump failure or the probable site of partial obstruction, on the basis of whether the topical fluorescein instilled for the primary test entered the lacrimal sac.

 

 

 

Fig: Jones dye testing. A. primary B. Secondary

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Schirmer test: Measures total tear secretion. A value <10mm is suggestive of dry eye.

 

 

Option B. Tear film break up time: Indicator of adequacy of mucin component of tear film. Less than 10 seconds indicates unstable tear film. The image below shows multiple dry spots in a fluorescein-stained tear film.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jones test is the test to assess the patency of the lacrimal pathway using fluorescein dye.

 

Ref: Patel J, Levin A, Patel BC. Epiphora Clinical Testing. [Updated 2023 Jul 25]. In: Stat Pearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): Stat Pearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557424/

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient came with complaints of a painful swelling in the region of left lacrimal sac associated with epiphora. He also gives history of fever and malaise. On examination, it is noted that the swelling is red, hot, firm and tender. The eyelids and cheek are also red and oedematous. On asking, he gives a history of having a dental abscess few days back. The ophthalmologist makes a diagnosis of Acute dacryocystitis in the stage of cellulitis. What treatment should be provided to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibiotics

 

Option C:

 

Treatment of acute dacryocystitis during stage of cellulitis:

 

  • Systemic and topical antibiotics to control infection.
  • Systemic anti-inflammatory analgesic drugs.
  • Hot fomentation to relieve pain and swelling.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dacryocystorhinostomy: Dacryocystorhinostomy is a surgical procedure used to create a new tear drainage pathway between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity. This is typically indicated in chronic dacryocystitis or after the acute infection has been resolved. It is not the first-line treatment for acute dacryocystitis in the cellulitis stage.

 

Option B. Abscess Drainage: Abscess drainage is performed if there is a formation of an abscess, which is a collection of pus. In acute dacryocystitis, abscess formation can occur, but drainage is indicated only if an abscess has actually formed.

 

Option D. Dacryocystectomy: Dacryocystectomy, the removal of the lacrimal sac, is rarely performed and typically reserved for cases where other treatments have failed or are not appropriate. It is not a standard treatment for acute dacryocystitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the stage of cellulitis in acute dacryocystitis, the most appropriate treatment is the administration of systemic Antibiotics. This approach is aimed at controlling the infection and preventing further complications. Once the acute infection is resolved, further evaluation and possibly surgical intervention (like dacryocystorhinostomy) might be considered, especially if there are underlying issues like nasolacrimal duct obstruction.

 

Ref: pg 395/lacrimal apparatus/6th edition comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

choices.text: 5*10 mm whatman 41 filter paper
5*35 mm whatman 41 filter paper
5*15 mm whatman 41 filter paper
5*50 mm whatman 41 filter paper

questions.text: Identify the strip used in the following test:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5*35 mm whatman 41 filter paper

 

Explanation:

 

Schirmer’s test

 

Schirmer's test is used to determine whether the eye produces enough tears to keep it moist. The test is performed by placing filter paper inside the lower lid of the eye. After 5 minutes, the paper is removed and tested for its moisture content.

 

A Schirmer test score >10 mm in 5 minutes is widely accepted as the normal value, whereas a score <5 mm is indicative of tear deficiency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

B. 5*35 mm whatman 41 filter paper is used for preparing Schirmer strips.

 

Ref: Pg 389/ lacrimal apparatus/ 6th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: What is the immediate treatment at this stage of dacryocystitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibiotics & drainage

 

Option C:

 

  • Lacrimal sac is the small sac located in the inner corner of the eye that collects tears and drains them into the nasal cavity.
  • An infection or inflammation of this sac is called dacryocystitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given clinical picture is suggestive of acute dacryocystitis with cellulitis and abscess formation. Thus, patient needs to be treated with systemic antibiotics and drainage of abscess.
